What is a protein diet and is it worth it to sit on
03 Nov 2019, 15:00 by Iya Zorina

1. What is a protein diet?

2. Why is it difficult to sit on it?

3. How exactly can a protein diet harm health?

4. So, not everyone can sit on a protein diet?

5. Well, does she have any advantages? Why is she so popular then?

6. So you just eat less?

7. Are these all the virtues?

8. Is there any difference on which protein diet to sit on?




Why is it good, how to choose the right option and not harm your health.


What is a protein diet?
Protein or high-protein diet (WB-diet) is a diet in which the daily protein intake exceeds the norm * of 0.8 g per 1 kg of body weight or more than 15-16% * of the total calorie intake. * Source: Protein and amino acid requirements in human nutrition Report of a joint FAO / WHO / UNU expert consultation (WHO Technical Report Series 935) * Source: A high ‚Äë protein diet for reducing body fat: mechanisms and possible caveats
In fact, any diet with so much protein can be considered high-protein, regardless of other conditions. There are many varieties of WB diets. You can conditionally divide them into three groups according to severity.

Virtually no limits. You do not need to monitor the amount of fats and carbohydrates, the main thing is to consume enough protein. You can reduce the calorie content of the diet by 300-500 kcal, choose healthy foods, give up sweets and alcohol, but this is optional.
Soft diets. Here you have to read the exact amount of nutrients and discard some foods. However, the level of fats and carbohydrates will remain acceptable, and the list of allowed foods will be wide. The soft ones include the Zone diet and nameless diet with clearly defined calories and percentages of BJU.
Rigid diets. There are serious restrictions on the amount of fats and carbohydrates or a strictly regulated list of products. These include the Atkins, Ducane, keto diet, and paleo diet.

In January 2019, U.S. magazine News & World Report published a rating * of the best diets. Health and nutrition experts checked 41 diets and set them according to safety and effectiveness. * Source: U.S. News ‚Äô41 Best Diets Overall
The soft WB diet The Zone was in the middle - at the 23rd place, and all the hard ones - at the tail of the list. The main reason for the low rating of such diets is that it is difficult to sit on them.


Why is it difficult to sit on it?
There are several reasons why tight diets can be a test for your willpower.

Feeling unwell in the early days. Keto, Atkins and Ducane diets limit the amount of carbohydrates to 20 g per day. Because of this, most people suffer from the so-called keto-flu: dizziness, weakness, headaches, nausea, vomiting, and insomnia. Over time, these symptoms disappear, but it can be difficult to hold out for the first week.
Lack of familiar food. Refusing carbohydrates means that you cannot eat bread, cereals, or even fruit, not to mention sweets. The Ducan diet, in addition to carbohydrates, also limits fats. So it is forbidden to eat on it not only all of the above, but also fatty meat, butter and cheese. On the paleo diet you can eat fruits and vegetables, but you can not any kinds of cereals, bread and dairy products.
More money for food. Since all hard high-protein diets include a lot of lean meat and prohibit cereals, pasta and potatoes, the value of your menu can increase. Especially when you are sick of chicken and want to diversify the menu with beef, turkey and red fish.
Difficulties with cooking. If you live in a family, you have to cook yourself separately. It is unlikely that you can dine in a cafe or dining room or buy ready-made food that suits your restrictions.

With soft diets, such difficulties will not affect you. Unlike hard, they can become part of your lifestyle for a long time. However, both of them under certain circumstances can harm health.


How exactly can a protein diet harm health?
An increased amount of protein has some health risks.
Kidney load
When you eat a lot of protein, the oxidation of its constituent parts - amino acids, increases the load on the kidneys. Even a short intake of large doses of protein accelerates * glomerular filtration - the first stage of urine formation, and changes the pH of the fluid. In the long run, this can harm the kidneys. * Source: Effect of short ‚Äë term high ‚Äë protein compared with normal ‚Äë protein diets on renal hemodynamics and associated variables in healthy young men
High animal protein intake is also associated * with a risk of kidney stones. * Source: Diet, fluid, or supplements for secondary prevention of nephrolithiasis: a systematic review and meta ‚Äë analysis of randomized trials
Metabolic risk
The composition of dietary protein includes branched chain amino acids, or BCAAs. * By-products that interfere with fatty acid oxidation accumulate in the body during BCAA processing. * Source: A high ‚Äë protein diet for reducing body fat: mechanisms and possible caveats
If there is a lot of fat in the diet, as in the keto or Atkins diet, under-oxidized substrates accumulate in the body, the action of insulin is disrupted, and the risk of metabolic disorders increases.
Deficiency of vitamins and minerals
This danger exists only for hard high-protein diets. Many carbohydrate-rich foods (fruits, vegetables, cereals) contain vitamins and minerals necessary for health.
Refusal of such food can cause a deficiency of nutrients. To prevent this, during the most severe phases of the diet, it is advised to take vitamin complexes.


So, not everyone can sit on a protein diet?
Yes, there are several conditions in which WB diets are contraindicated:

Abnormalities in kidney function or a tendency to stone, as well as risk factors for kidney disease: hypertension, diabetes, cardiovascular disease. To find out if everything is in order, take a creatinine test, a HbA1C hemoglobin test for diabetes, and a urine test for proteinuria (the appearance of protein in the urine).
Pregnancy. Increased protein intake during gestation may result in High ‚Äë protein diets during pregnancy: healthful or harmful for offspring? to reduce fetal growth, high blood pressure and increased secretion of cortisol in response to stress.



Well, does she have any advantages? Why is she so popular then?
Probably the main plus of protein diets is the lack of a constant feeling of hunger.
Protein increases * the production of satiety hormones and reduces the concentration of ghrelin, a hormone that increases appetite. Therefore, you consume fewer calories, even without restriction. * Source: A high ‚Äë protein diet for reducing body fat: mechanisms and possible caveats
Moreover, protein of animal origin - from meat, milk, eggs - is absorbed better and faster provides a feeling of satiety than protein from vegetable sources - legumes, tofu.


It turns out you just eat less?
Not only. In addition to suppressing hunger, WB diets help you spend more calories without any exercise.
The fact is that protein is the most energy-intensive nutrient. It takes 3 times more energy to digest it * than to process carbohydrates, and 10 times more than fat burning. * Source: A high ‚Äë protein diet for reducing body fat: mechanisms and possible caveats
The body can spend * up to 70‚Äì213 kcal per day only to digest and absorb protein. * Source: The effect of protein intake on 24 ‚Äë h energy expenditure during energy restriction, Effect of fat ‚Äë reduced diets on 24 ‚Äë h energy expenditure: comparisons between animal protein, vegetable protein, and carbohydrate
Moreover, this substance helps to change body composition, which also affects * calorie expenditure. About 50‚Äì80% of all energy * is spent on maintaining muscle mass, while adipose tissue consumes virtually nothing. Thus, the more muscle, the more energy the body spends. * Source: Relationship between resting metabolic rate and the composition of the fat ‚Äë free mass * Source: Body weight control and energy expenditure
Dietary protein increases * muscle protein synthesis and prevents muscle loss even with a calorie deficit. However, if you want to build muscle, just protein is not enough: you also need carbohydrates and strength training. * Source: Effects of Protein Supplementation on Performance and Recovery in Resistance and Endurance Training


Are these all the virtues?
Another high-protein diet is good * for bones. Protein stimulates the production of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1), a hormone that increases bone growth. * Source: Controversies Surrounding High-Protein Diet Intake: Satiating Effect and Kidney and Bone Health
In addition, the protein reduces the concentration of parathyroid hormone, which promotes the release of calcium from the bones into the bloodstream and activates osteoclasts - cells that destroy bone tissue.
Studies confirm that a high-protein diet positively * affects bone health, especially the lumbar spine, and * reduces the risk of fractures in older adults. * Source: Dietary protein and bone health: a systematic review and meta ‚Äë analysis from the National Osteoporosis Foundation * Source: Prospective study of dietary protein intake and risk of hip fracture in postmenopausal women


Is there any difference on which protein diet to sit on?
Sure. The better you choose a diet, the less you will suffer. First of all, pay attention to the following points.
Your eating habits
If some products are of particular importance to you, it is better to choose a diet on which you can eat them at least in small quantities. So it will be easier for you to adhere to a diet without breakdowns and stress.
So, if you can‚Äôt live without bread and cereals, choose a protein diet without a ban on carbohydrates or an option with a slight restriction, for example, the Zone.
For fanatical meat-eaters, the Ducan diet is suitable, and for those who also like fatty foods, a keto or Atkins diet. To those whoindifferent to dairy products, flour and sweets, but loves meat, fruits and vegetables, paleo is ideal.
Desired weight loss rate
It is impossible to accurately predict how many kilograms you lose on a particular diet - it depends on the characteristics of your body. Studies give only approximate figures for the most popular options:

Dukan diet Assessment of food intakes for women adopting the high protein Dukan diet - up to 15 kg in 8-10 weeks;
paleo diet Effects of Popular Diets without Specific Calorie Targets on Weight Loss Outcomes: Systematic Review of Findings from Clinical Trials - up to 7 kg for six months and up to 9 - for a year;
Zone - from 2 to 7 kg for six months;
Effect of a High-Protein Diet versus Standard-Protein Diet on Weight Loss and Biomarkers of Metabolic Syndrome diet: A Randomized Clinical Trial with a deficit of 500 kcal per day and 1.34 g of protein per 1 kg of weight - up to 7 kg per six months;
Atkins diet Effects of Popular Diets without Specific Calorie Targets on Weight Loss Outcomes: Systematic Review of Findings from Clinical Trials - from 2 to 7 kg for six months;
Effects of Low ‚Äë Carbohydrate vs Low ‚Äë Fat Diets on Weight Loss and Cardiovascular Risk Factors ketogenic diet - about 6 kg in six months.

Sport or physical activity
